newsitem.title: UK: IPE natgas ends weaker in summer, December climbs.
newsitem.headline: IPE natgas ends weaker in summer, December climbs.

text.p: IPE natural gas futures ended the afternoon session mostly weaker on Tuesday, with a glut of summer gas preying on the physical market, brokers said.
"There's plenty of summer gas around, that's why we didn't understand the gains last week," said one broker.
Afternoon trade was thin, adding just 25 lots, or five deals, to the morning total of 80 lots traded.

Dealers said that pressure on the front end of the forward curve caused by unseasonally warm temperatures was having a knock-on effect, particularly after TransCo sold gas on the flexibility mechanism over the weekend.
May and June both slipped 0.05 p/th to 10.15 p/th, while July shed 0.125 to trade at $10.10 p/th. August traded unchanged at 10.20 p/th.
March and April 1998 also slipped lower, but December this year climbed a modest 0.035 to trade at 14.285.
Warm temperatures in the UK were expected to ease, buoying gas demand later in the week, forecasters said.
The UK Met Office said on Tuesday in its three-day forecast that it foresaw "rain in the north spreading southwards followed by much colder weather with wintry showers over Scotland."
